text: After searching for scholarly articles that explore community, the results produced numerous papers and books that examine community around one's identity and personal needs.Merriam-Webster defines community as "a unified body of individuals."I would define community as a group of people that share a mutual identity, whether it be race, gender, religion, or sexual orientation. Furthermore, I believe a community is comprised of people who strongly associate themselves with that group.For me, an "online community" is one where the definitions above are present but, perhaps even more important, people are able to develop a true social presence. In other words, members of the group must be able to develop and convey a true sense of themselves that includes their personality, passions, interests, and emotions. In order to do this, members must engage clearly and frequently, as well as communicate effectively. I really like the book's definition of online communities as a virtual space where people "come together in meaningful ways" and with a sense of "purpose." Additionally, it is important for whichever platform is being utilized to have a clear structure. This is my vision of a successful online community. It's when people bring all parts of themselves to an online space, using a variety of technology, and are able to use the structure of the virtual space to help other members gain a perspective (and hopefully an accurate one) of who they are. Community members learn about one another, develop common interests, and eventually trust each other enough to rely on members and look to each other to learn more about others and themselves. With our culture being heavily dependent on body language to help us decipher messages and a need for face-to-face interactions, I believe developing a strong, viable online community poses great difficulty. I come from a background where online communities feel a little unnatural, so I am very excited to stretch myself outside of my comfort zone and I look forward to developing peer relationships in a virtual space. After reading the first chapter of "Building online learning communities" and searching for some articles and Wikipedia information, I have had an initial conception of "online learning community". In my opinion, two kinds of actors- facilitator and learner are fundamental factors in online learning community. Various online activities performed by these two kinds of actors comprise a online social context. This constructivist context is called online learning community. More importantly, only this constructivist context can be considered as "online learning community". Communities which are used as a platform to deliver teaching materials by instructors are not "online learning community".In order to form a social constructivist context, facilitator should clarify course goals, objectives, expected outcomes, guidelines, collaborative assignments to learners. During the learning process, the learner who is open-minded sharing, self-motivated and self-disciplined are more likely to be a successful online learner. Online activities (performed by both learners and facilitator) include social presence, collaborative activities, interactions and communications, reflective and transformative learning, etc. Details of these concepts please watch my Prezi shown below.My Prezi: What's online learning community?I believe community is important in online learning spaces. Because I believe learning is a social process. Online community is the space people share their thoughts, ideas, reflections, skills, technologies and make communications and interactions with others. Only through this self-learning and collaborative learning process can people construct their knowledge system.Thanks guys. Could you please tell me whether you can watch the Prezi or not?

As I reflect on the idea of community, think about the reading in chapter 1, and the information that I found online, is the fact that the ideas around and the definition of community has made many changes in the past several years. _My first thought on "community" sent me to my childhood neighborhood. _A place where a group of people lived and interacted together. _Merriam and Webster define community as "a group of people who live in the same area, a group of people who have the same interest, religion or race". _This definition I would say has been the main idea of community for decades. However, now we have a new and modern idea of something called the "Virtual Community". _The internet has taken the idea of living in the same area away. _Now we are able to be a part of a community regardless of our location. _I have been part of an online community for the past three years here at the University. _During my first year it was a time of intense learning. _I was not used to the online learning tools, and it took me a while to feel confident in myself as a learner. _Chapter one did a nice job of laying out what it takes to be successful with online communities. _At first, I had a hard time trusting myself to be able to complete the work without the instructor on hand. _I also had to develop a game plan for myself as much of the learning and time frame is based on your time line. _After three years of being a part of the online community. _I feel that I know what I am doing. _I am willing to put myself out their in my posts and willing to share my ideas with the class and the instructor. What I love about online communities is that it bring together a group of people who may never have connected. _I also love online communities because I am able to work at my own pace when it works for me. _It is fun to see what others are doing and thinking about in posts and chats. _This to me is why I believe that online communities are so important. _I have been amazed how much I have learned in the past three years and all the great people that I have been in a "community" with.

When I think about defining online community, I think about how I as a program evaluator would think about it as an intervention in learning and what that may "look like". I reviewed a few published studies that evaluated different online communities (learning and professional). _The online communities that "succeeded" by some measure included these aspects: high engagement (measured by frequency of participation, depth of participation, or particular participation patterns), shared sense of vision (in most cases this was centered on a particular aspect of learning), _and sense of belonging or community loyalty (self report paired with measures of participation). The studies also discussed motivations such as relevance of knowledge sharing in community and perceived advantage of belonging and participating. The studies also either measured or discussed the role of self efficacy in fostering engagement. Participants needed to be confident enough in their own ability to share knowledge to be engaged.In a learning community it seems like it would be important to figure out what strengths different members bring to the table, scaffold discussions so that varied expertise is valued, and establish the trust among members early and consistently. I liked the "Building Online Learning Communities' reference to conscious community - the need for personal growth and transformation as part of that definition.The other piece that seemed missing from the studies I found was thinking about the role of discourse in building knowledge or learning in the community. It was perhaps implicit in the different measures of weblogs aItics from these studies but that seems to miss the constructivist thinking that R described in Prezi.Thinking about the definition makes me realize the challenges of thinking about evaluation with respect to online communities.

I envision "online community" as a place where people of all kind from all over the world comes together online to work and or learn together. Online communities occur when individuals come together for a sense of purpose. I would say that our class on this Ning website is an example of an online community. We come together and engage in conversations to enhance our learning and understanding. Slowly we become comfortable with one another so that the space shared in our online community is a safe place. We all have a common interest in choosing this class and taking this class. Each person may have a different reason for taking this class as we stated in our voicethreads the first week of class, but we had the option to come together to take this class and share the space here. I envision online learning communities as a place where people could freely express their self and keep an open mind to what they would like to share with other people within the community.

I firmly believe that community is important in online learning spaces because without a doubt it builds collaboration. Without community (and a strong community that is), you lack engagement, trust, and respect from members of the online learning space, which makes the online space seem void; serving no purpose. Community in an online learning space allows members to create a sense of ownership and connection to others. In the paper, Building a Dynamic Online Learning Community among Adult Learners, it notes evidence of an online community forming from three markers: active participation, the forming of a shared identity, and the establishment of a social network. Without participation, you lack interaction, and therefore lack any opportunities to learn from each other (such through constructivism or active learning [noted in our book]). Our book really sums it up well in the first chapter, "The development of community as part of the learning process helps create a learning experience that is powerful and rich."

An online leaning community is a destination on the Internet where where the needs of members are addressed through individual-to-individual sharing of knowledge and information (Online learning community, Wikipedia). Such a community is aimed at fostering the learning needs of members by using social networking or computer applications such as texts, audio, or video. The literature does not describe a pre-determined look or feel for an online learning community. However, it is important for members to feel a sense of belonging and that their learning needs are addressed by participation.One common example of a learning community is Community of practice, defined as "a group of people who share a craft and/or a profession" (Community of practice, Wikipedia). Those who form or belong to a community of practice do so to advance their professional objectives by sharing knowledge related to their particular field or profession.

Based on my experience online and on what Ive read so far, I believe that community is important to the success of online spaces, and especially to the construction of learning online. Social constructivist theory posits that learning is created as a social activity, so it would seem necessary to foster learning through the development of community. And George Siemens?theory of connectivity talks about developing and maintaining connections between people as critical to constructing learning. Many of the papers I read for the Intro to LT class described cooperative and transformative learning as needing a high degree of interaction among students and also between students and teachers to succeed. I would like to read more about the relationship between online community development and transformational learning.When an online community really works, perhaps it can draw its participants back inside again and again in the same way as a student hangout (of the brick-and-mortar variety) might_in the same way as the student room in the East Asian Studies department did when I was an undergrad. Maybe it can become the place people want to be for interesting discussion and encouragement and learning. I would like to learn more about ways to construct online spaces that nourish that sort of inviting environment that feels appealing, supportive, and challenging, so that students develop the intrinsic motivation to log on often_to see our friends and colleagues and learn something new from each other.

I definitely agree that an online learning environment has certain advantages in creating _opportunities for connection and learning:- In a physical space, there are restrictions on how many people can interact at one time, whereas in an online environment there aren't really physical limitations for how many people can join. - In an online space both public and private conversations can occur (more or less) simultaneously. In an online space, it is possible to pay attention to the main class discussion and connect with class members individually, in the same span of time, whereas in a f2f class it's rude to have side conversations during a discussion! - An online community affords more breadth and depth in a discussion. There's more breadth because everyone gets to write their response, so we get to hear from everyone's unique perspective. As far as depth, in a spoken conversation, there's a "flow", and sometimes things get interrupted, or topics are passed over that could be discussions more deeply. There's more depth with an online conversation board because it's easy to return to past discussions and add more thoughts. Also, when we write text, that makes it much easier to reply exactly to what another person has said. This speaks to what F was saying about an environment that is "challenging". In part, an online discussion is challenging because we have so much more breadth and depth in our discussions to contend with.- Online spaces can be appealing - not always in the same ways as physical spaces, but both can be aesthetically appealing. It's usually easier/less expensive to "remodel" an online space to better suite its members. Often there's more "room" in an online space for members to add their own individuality, like how we can add our personal photos to this group site. I'd like to see us try to do that in a classroom on campus! :-)

In an online space, it is possible to pay attention to the main class discussion and connect with class members individually, in the same span of time, whereas in a f2f class it's rude to have side conversations during a discussion! - An online community affords more breadth and depth in a discussion. There's more breadth because everyone gets to write their response, so we get to hear from everyone's unique perspective. As far as depth, in a spoken conversation, there's a "flow", and sometimes things get interrupted, or topics are passed over that could be discussions more deeply. There's more depth with an online conversation board because it's easy to return to past discussions and add more thoughts. Maddix in Christian Education Journal (Series 3, Vol. 10, No.1). _I am neither Christian nor religious, but I found this article intriguing because it deals with the idea of larger community values within an individual classroom community. _In Christian universities one of the elements of their teaching is helping young people in the forming and shaping of their faith. _Classes, therefore, are not just about the content (e.g., history, chemistry), but about modeling Christian values and beliefs. _The concern is that in online classes these values and beliefs may not be modeled. _Moreover, some theologians argue that embodiment is key to molding these beliefs and values and physical presence is necessary. _Maddix presents an alternative viewpoint through various research. _Of particular interest to me is John Greshams research that argues for a _divine pedagogy?or __the pedagogy of the incarnation [that] points to the realm of the student's life experience as the locus of divine saving action?(Maddix, p. 142 and Gresham, 2006, p. 26). _In other words, to use Greshams language again, _divine pedagogy includes a communal dimension similar to the church, [it] provides active participation of students in the learning process, and is relevant to online education because it is rich in symbols and signs that communicate meaning?(Maddix, p. 142 and Gresham 2006, p. 27-28). _I read such statements as a redefining of community or rather we must not assume that we are a community simply because we share similar values and beliefs. _Rather we must continuously build community and allow the actors to be active, challenged, and provide space for difference and growth. _In other words, we cant just say our community has these values and beliefs and that you will pick them up simply by your presence. _I like this.In sum, then, an online community really needs to be genuine in its efforts to be a community. _We can't just be together in this space, we need to engage in it.

I couldnt help but think that talkers _win?in f-2-f classes, but writers _win?in online classes. _But, dont good writers always win? _That is, ultimately in higher education if you are a strong writer no matter f-2-f or online you will come out on top because after all the major assignments always involve writing. _How can we change that dynamic, even just a little, so that more people can win?Finally, I am intrigued by the difference between presence and interaction as described on page 12. _I think about some stories I have read about how people have become actually lonelier or depressed through social media such as Facebook (FB). _In most of these stories the key was that on FB and other social media people are marketing themselves. _That is, they are posting images of themselves on vacation or some other fantastic place because they want to show the world how great their life is. _Its almost like marketing a product. _If this is true, then wouldnt that be considered presence, but not true interaction? _As in, the comments below the wonderful picture, _looks like fun,?_you look amazing!? etc.? _It seems to me friends are acknowledging presence not truly interacting. _OK, dont get me wrong, I am just as guilty of this stuff as anyone_Im just contemplating this idea. In looking for an article that discusses community I found an interesting one: _Developing Online Learning Communities?by Mark. A. Maddix in Christian Education Journal (Series 3, Vol. 10, No.1). _I am neither Christian nor religious, but I found this article intriguing because it deals with the idea of larger community values within an individual classroom community. _In Christian universities one of the elements of their teaching is helping young people in the forming and shaping of their faith. _Classes, therefore, are not just about the content (e.g., history, chemistry), but about modeling Christian values and beliefs. _The concern is that in online classes these values and beliefs may not be modeled. _Moreover, some theologians argue that embodiment is key to molding these beliefs and values and physical presence is necessary. _Maddix presents an alternative viewpoint through various research. _Of particular interest to me is John Greshams research that argues for a _divine pedagogy?or __the pedagogy of the incarnation [that] points to the realm of the student's life experience as the locus of divine saving action?(Maddix, p. 142 and Gresham, 2006, p. 26). _In other words, to use Greshams language again, _divine pedagogy includes a communal dimension similar to the church, [it] provides active participation of students in the learning process, and is relevant to online education because it is rich in symbols and signs that communicate meaning?(Maddix, p. 142 and Gresham 2006, p. 27-28). _I read such statements as a redefining of community or rather we must not assume that we are a community simply because we share similar values and beliefs. _Rather we must continuously build community and allow the actors to be active, challenged, and provide space for difference and growth. _In other words, we cant just say our community has these values and beliefs and that you will pick them up simply by your presence. _I like this.In sum, then, an online community really needs to be genuine in its efforts to be a community. _We can't just be together in this space, we need to engage in it.

I see community as a group of people sharing the same area of interest or experience - and in thinking about the Community of Practice, I was drawn to Richard Millington's statement that, "Every online community lives within an ecosystem. Even a community that defines its ecosystem is still encompassed within it." He goes on to say that, "To make matters more confusing, a community can exist in more than one ecosystem." So, I think of my profession of dental hygiene, living within the ecosystem of organized dentistry. Every-so-often, state Boards of Dentistry make major changes to the individual services that a dental hygienist can legally provide to their patients. So, this larger ecosystem change can greatly impact my dental hygiene community. Additionally, these dental hygiene members can be affected by other ecosystems, like the dental insurance ecosystem, which could decide that having one's teeth cleaned, x-rayed and examined should no longer be a covered benefit, which would have profound effects on both my dental hygiene community and its larger ecosystem of organized dentistry, at a minimum. So, this has caused me to think about community not as an insular, members-only club, but rather as a dynamic group which is constantly acting and reacting to what's taking place both within and without the community - the "issues, media, people, competition and trends" (Millington) affecting this group of people are what really constitute an online community.
